citation.article-title: Fibrella aestuarina gen. nov., sp. nov., a filamentous bacterium of the family Cytophagaceae isolated from a tidal flat, and emended description of the genus Rudanella Weon et al. 2008
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Fibrella (Fib.rel′la. L. fem. n. fibra a fibre or filament; L. dim. suff. -ella; N.L. fem. n. Fibrella a small fibre, referring to the ability of the type species to produce filaments).
Cells are facultatively anaerobic, Gram-staining-negative, non-motile rods that form multicellular filaments.
Predominant cellular fatty acids are summed feature 3 (C16 : 1ω7c and/or iso-C15 : 0 2-OH), C16 : 1ω5c, iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 0 and iso-C17 : 0 3-OH.
The major polar lipid is phosphatidylethanolamine; several unidentified aminolipids, phospholipids and aminophospholipids also occur.
The only respiratory quinone is MK-7.
The G+C content of the type strain of the type species is 56.5 mol%.
Phylogenetically, the genus belongs to the family Cytophagaceae within the phylum Bacteroidetes.
The type species is Fibrella aestuarina.
